title: Edinburgh,
author: Masson, Rosaline Orme.
snippet: been married, and here the Queen had founded a magnificent Abbey. The two villages on the opposite sides of the Firth of Forth are still called North Queensferry and South Queensferry.

title: Journal of a lady of quality;
author: Schaw, Janet
snippet: * Queensferry is a small seaport on the Firth of Forth, eight miles west of Edinburgh. South Queensferry is in Linlithgowshire and North Queensferry in Fifeshire. A ferry at that time and until 1890 connected the two places.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: The Duke rode with us all the way as Lord Lieutenant of the county, until we arrived at Dalmeny, where Lord Hopetoun met us and rode with us. At eleven we reached the South Queensferry, where we got out of our carriage and embarked in a little steamer ; the ladies and gentlemen and our carriages going in another. We went a little way up the Forth, to see Hopetoun House, Lord Hopetoun's, which is beautifully situated between Hopetoun and Dal meny.

title: Provost-Marshal: a romance of the middle shires
author: Moncreiff, Frederick Charles
snippet: For a space he gazed moodily out upon the water; he saw the ships going backwards and forwards, and in those days there were many, for the trade was brisk with Antwerp, Bordeaux, Lisbon, and many other foreign ports. He saw the richly wooded banks on the far side of the water, and the smoke rising from the little town of South Queensferry opposite to him. He noted all the islands laid out as on a map below, and

title: Reminiscences of childhood at Inverkeithing;
author: Simson, James
snippet: tain of the okl rickety steam ferryboat told me to "jump aboard," when I made a trip to the South Queensferry, which was an important event in my experience there.

title: Provost-Marshal: a romance of the middle shires
author: Moncreiff, Frederick Charles
snippet: He was no longer in doubt. So they passed out of Fife in a ship which brought them quickly to the South Queensferry. And the boy said to himself, " Surely this medicinar, for all his grave airs, is a great ass."

title: The silent watchers ;
author: Copplestone, Bennet
snippet: Upon the following Saturday, May 27th, I was invited to lunch in one of the battleships, but upon arrival at South Queensferry, I found the Fleet under Short Notice for sea, and no one was allowed to leave the ships, or to receive friends on board. It was a beautiful day, the long-, light- coloured Cats and the Futurist -grey battleships were a most noble sight, but I felt too much like a Peri shut out of Paradise to be happy in observing them.
